p: Recently, tungsten telluride (WTe 2), as a member of the TMDC family, has drawn tremendous research interest since the discovery of its large non-saturating positive magnetoresistance (MR) behavior, which was attributed to its perfect electron–hole compensation. Theoretical calculations and experiments have indicated that WTe 2 has a complicated electronic structure with more than two bands presenting at the Fermi level [ 17]. Meanwhile, it was believed to a wonderful candidate for the type-II Weyl semimetal [ 18] and quantum spin Hall insulator material [ 19]. Additionally, many other remarkable properties of WTe 2 have also been revealed, such as the temperature-driven Lifshitz transition [ 20], pressure-induced superconductivity [ 21], linear Nernst response [ 22], etc. Interestingly, although all of the TMDCs have the same formula, the atomic structure of 1T’-phase WTe 2 is totally different from the other TMDCs. 1T’-WTe 2 exhibits a distorted structure relative to the 1T’ phase. Both Raman [ 23– 24] and first-principles [ 25– 26] calculations have been used to indicate that monolayer 1T’-WTe 2 has a highly in-plane anisotropic crystal structure, in addition to anisotropic electrical, thermal and optical properties [ 23– 26]. However, most of the results are based on theoretical demonstrations of the anisotropic phenomenon, rather than further quantitative data for the characterization the natural anisotropy of 1T’-WTe 2.
